awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrated mechanisms underlying the regulation of intestinal form and function
awd_abstract_narration:
The small intestine is the principal gateway for the uptake of nutrients from meals, the largest of the body's endocrine and immune organs, and hosts an immense bacterial community that is thought to influence all realms of the body's physiology. The intestine also can remodel its structure and function to match meal size, to accommodate changes in diet, and to compensate for loss due to disease or surgery, but little is currently known about the precise mechanisms that underlie this remodeling. The ultimate goal of this collaborative research is to identify the signaling and structural mechanisms that enable the vertebrate intestine to modulate structure and function. Rather than relying on traditional laboratory research animals to achieve this goal, this program takes advantage of the extreme ability of some snakes (pythons, boas, and rattlesnakes) to remodel their small intestine with each meal. By comparing the cellular and molecular responses of the small intestine to feeding and fasting among snakes that feed regularly versus sporadically, and between snakes and other vertebrates, coupled with available genomic resources, this research program will provide new insight into the mechanisms that underlie intestinal remodeling in vertebrates. An exciting novelty of this research is the incorporation of non-traditional model species (i.e., snakes) that have the potential to reveal previously unknown or overlooked mechanisms and that may be important for driving new discoveries for the therapeutic treatment of intestinal diseases. The project's outreach components include workshops on the generation and analyses of gene expression data, and public lectures and animal-based exhibitions to local schools, camps, and museums.

Vertebrates possess the physiological capacities to alter intestinal performance that are adaptively linked to their feeding habits. For example, species that naturally experience long episodes of fasting between large meals (e.g., sit-and-wait foraging snakes) experience rapid upregulation of intestinal form and function with feeding, and subsequent intestinal atrophy and downregulation following digestion. In contrast, frequently feeding species (e.g., active-foraging snakes) experience only modest change in intestinal form and function with each meal. Currently unknown are the cellular and molecular mechanisms that underlie the structural and functional flexibility of the intestine, and whether such mechanisms are shared across vertebrates that widely or narrowly regulate intestinal performance. By leveraging the extreme range in intestinal responses exhibited by snakes and other vertebrates, and recently available genomic resources, this research program will identify the underlying mechanisms of intestinal flexibility and. test whether these mechanisms are shared across lineages and regulatory phenotypes. This goal will be accomplished by pursuing three aims: (1) identify the cellular and structural mechanisms that underlie the modulation of intestinal form, and whether form dictates the regulation of intestinal function; (2) link transcriptional and post-translational mechanisms to phenotypic changes in intestinal structure and function; and (3) test whether shared or unique sets of molecular mechanisms drive similar phenotypic responses among vertebrates. Ultimately, this research will identify the signaling and structural mechanisms by which vertebrates modulate intestinal form and function.

por.por_cntn:
The small intestine serves a broad range of functions, including digestion and absorption, metabolic regulation, immune response, and hormone secretion. Vertebrates possess the adaptive capacity to modulate intestinal structure and function to meet changes in diet and digestive demand. For most vertebrates, epithelial cells cycle constantly, as the crypts between villi generate new enterocytes that migrate to villus tips, where they die and are expelled. Some vertebrate lineages are, however, outstanding in their capacity to massively differentially regulate intestinal form and function. The most extraordinary intestinal regulatory capacity belongs to heavy-bodied snakes like the Burmese python: within 24 hours of a python feeding, their small intestinal wet mass doubles and their metabolism increases 44-fold. Notably, pythons and other snake species achieve this extreme degree of regeneration from intestinal tissue that lacks the standard crypt-villus axis patterning observed in other vertebrates. The overarching goal of this research program was to investigate the physiological, cellular, and molecular mechanisms by which snakes undergo these extreme regenerative events, and compare this with intestinal regulation in other vertebrates to provide insights into tissue regeneration and identify core shared features underlying intestinal regulation in vertebrates.

During this project we have published multiple papers that address the physiology of vertebrate intestinal regulation and regeneration that have provide new insights into the  previously poorly understood interactions between growth and stress response pathways in intestinal regulation and regenerative growth. Models derived from our work have developed the hypothesis of a switch-like role between stress response and growth signaling pathways to balance the need to mitigate metabolic stress with regenerating new tissue to support intestinal absorption during intestinal regulation and regeneration. Our publications have provided new insight into the role of stress response pathways (e.g., NRF2 and UPR) in intestinal regulation and broadly in vertebrate regenerative capacity. Specifically, our work has demonstrated new evidence that these stress response pathways modulate the outputs of growth pathway signaling (e.g. Insulin, mTOR) and have the potential to effectively ‘unlock’ vertebrate intestinal regenerative capacity.

Relative to the three main objectives of the proposed research, we have identified key gene expression and post-translational modifications that are associated with extreme intestinal regeneration that clarify how stress response and growth pathways ‘communicate’ and interact in the context of regenerative growth in the intestine. We have demonstrated that these links between growth and stress response pathways show conserved mechanisms of action in distinct vertebrate lineages that appear to have independently evolved the capacity to widely-regulate intestinal form and function, indicating that a common set of mechanisms that are highly conserved across vertebrates are involved in distinct lineages of widely-regulating species. Further, our recent and ongoing work has linked this extensive regeneration to rare cell type populations (Best4+ enterocytes) which display extensive heterogeneity in gene expression, pathway signaling, and intracellular communication that link to major tissue restructuring and play a key signaling role during regeneration. These Best4+ cells are interesting because while present in snakes, fish, and humans, they appear to be absent from the mouse, which has led to the role of these cells being under-appreciated by prior studies.

In addition to accomplishments across all main objectives, genomic and functional genomic datasets collected as part of this work enabled an additional collection of papers by leveraging these resources and expertise we developed as part of this project. This led to us being well-positioned to make other significant contributions, including work with collaborators to interpret results from a mouse model of a knockout in a key gene in this UPR pathway in the intestine, contributing the first true chromosome-level reptile genome (for the Prairie Rattlesnake), and contributing new insight into snake W chromosomes and to vertebrate transposable element evolution. Similarly, by leveraging resources generated here and our expertise in stress responses, we contributed multiple studies that identified the genomic mechanisms underlying venom gene regulation.

This work has been widely disseminated through the publication of over 20 papers, and will continue with multiple additional papers currently in various stages of review and preparation. The project has contributed to training of 8 PhD students, and to the training of two postdoctoral researchers. Research from this project has been used to convey broad principles of evolution, physiology and genomics, and the value of basic research to inform our understanding of biology to a very large audience through many invited talks and in undergraduate and graduate courses. Our work has also been prominently featured in multiple news stories and other media (including a the NY Times) that have been used for educational purposes and disseminated to the public, and was featured in an entire chapter of a popular science book “Life’s Edge” by Carl Zimmer, an award winning popular science writer and regular contributor to the New York Times.
